title: 108_s631
content: The Act clarifies section 3626(j)(1)(D)(ii) of title 39, United States Code regarding cooperative mailings. Section 3626(j) of title 39, United States Code is amended to allow authorized organizations with a business relationship to apply former section 4452 (b) or (c) rates for mail matter sent on behalf of entities described in subparagraph (B)(ii). Entities described in subparagraph (B)(ii) are organizations or individuals not authorized. This paragraph prohibits mail advertising products or services at discounted rates if they would otherwise be excluded from such rates by other provisions. SEC. 3. CONFLICT OF INTEREST. Section 3626 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to address conflicts of interest in contracts between qualified nonprofit organizations and commercial entities for fundraising or counseling services. The contract must be approved in advance by the nonprofit organization's governing body to avoid a presumption against eligibility. The amended Section 3626 of title 39, United States Code addresses conflicts of interest in contracts between qualified nonprofit organizations and commercial entities for fundraising or counseling services. The contract must be approved in advance by the nonprofit organization's governing body to avoid a presumption against eligibility. If a conflict of interest is found, the presumption may be rebutted by demonstrating that the contract meets the required standards. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The Sense of Congress is that this Act only pertains to postage rates authorized under section 3626 of title 39, United States Code. It also clarifies that the United States Postal Service retains the authority to apply regular postage rates, enforce criminal laws, and revoke nonprofit mail permits for authorized organizations. The Act prohibits schemes to obtain money through false representations in the mail, conducting lotteries or gift enterprises through the mail, and broadly prohibits fraudulent activities. The Act prohibits fraudulent activities using the Postal Service and does not limit the authority of the Attorney General to address consumer protection issues related to criminal or fraudulent fundraising practices. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE AND APPLICATION. The amendments made by this Act apply to mail sent before, on, or after the enactment date, with section 3 becoming effective for contracts entered into after enactment. This Act does not create a cause of action against the USPS to recover postage paid before enactment. It also does not prohibit the government from continuing civil actions initiated before enactment. The Act applies to mail sent before or after the enactment date, with section 3 effective for contracts entered into after enactment. It does not create a cause of action against USPS for postage paid before enactment or prohibit the government from continuing civil actions initiated before enactment.
